symptoms.second: Small, skin-colored bumps (whiteheads) or darkened bumps (blackheads) on the skin.
Inflamed, red bumps (papules) or pus-filled bumps (pustules) on the skin.
Large, painful lumps beneath the surface of the skin.
Excess production of sebum leading to shiny or greasy skin.
Acne lesions may leave scars, especially if they are picked or squeezed.

cures.second: Over-the-counter creams with benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid.
Antibiotics, retinoids, or hormonal treatments prescribed by a dermatologist.
Chemical peels, laser therapy, or drainage and extraction of large cysts.
Gentle cleansing, avoiding harsh products, and using non-comedogenic moisturizers.
Managing stress, maintaining a healthy diet, and avoiding picking or squeezing pimples.

prevention.second: Use a mild cleanser to remove excess oil and debris.
Touching the face with dirty hands can introduce bacteria.
Select skincare and makeup products labeled as non-comedogenic.
Consume a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
Stress reduction techniques, such as meditation or exercise, may help prevent flare-ups.

symptoms.second: Irregular, depigmented patches on the skin.
Hair in affected areas may turn prematurely white or gray.
Often appears on both sides of the body.
Loss of color in the iris (ocular or segmental vitiligo).
Skin in affected areas may be more sensitive to sunlight.

cures.second: Steroid creams to reduce inflammation and depigmentation.
Suppress the immune response in affected areas.
Exposure to UVB light to stimulate repigmentation.
Camouflage affected areas with pigmented tattoos.
Lightening unaffected skin to match depigmented areas.

prevention.second: Use sunscreen to protect depigmented areas from sunburn.
Use makeup or concealing agents to cover affected areas.
Techniques like meditation to manage emotional stress.
Monitor for new depigmented areas and seek early treatment.
Ensure a well-balanced diet, including sources of vitamin B12.

symptoms.second: Red, raised, and itchy circular patches (ringworm).
Skin may appear scaly with peeling edges.
Candidiasis may cause white discharge in affected areas.

cures.second: In severe cases, oral antifungal medications.
Keep affected areas clean and dry.

prevention.second: Regular bathing and keeping skin dry.
Treat fungal infections promptly to prevent spread.
Monitor for any signs of recurrence.
